abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Clinical severity of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) outcomes could be influenced by genetic polymorphisms in angiotensin I-converting enzyme (<jats:italic>ACE1</jats:italic>) and <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic>. This study aims to examine three polymorphisms (rs1978124, rs2285666, and rs2074192) on the <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> gene and <jats:italic>ACE1</jats:italic> rs1799752 (I/D) in patients who have coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) with various SARS-CoV-2 variants.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Based on polymerase chain reaction-based genotyping, four polymorphisms in the <jats:italic>ACE1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> genes have been identified in 2023 deceased patients and 2307 recovered patients.
</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> rs2074192 TT genotype was associated with the COVID-19 mortality in all three variants, whereas the CT genotype was associated with the Omicron BA.5 and Delta variants. <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> rs1978124 TC genotypes were related to COVID-19 mortality in the Omicron BA.5 and Alpha variants, but TT genotypes were related to COVID-19 mortality in the Delta variant. It was found that <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> rs2285666 CC genotypes were associated with COVID-19 mortality in Delta and Alpha variants, and CT genotypes in Delta variants. There was an association between <jats:italic>ACE1</jats:italic> rs1799752 DD and ID genotypes in the Delta variant and COVID-19 mortality, whereas there was no association in the Alpha or Omicron BA.5 variants. In all variants of SARS-CoV-2, CDCT and TDCT haplotypes were more common. In Omicron BA.5 and Delta, CDCC and TDCC haplotypes were linked with COVID-19 mortality. In addition to COVID-19 mortality, the CICT, TICT, and TICC were significantly correlated.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The <jats:italic>ACE1</jats:italic>/<jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> polymorphisms had an impact on COVID-19 infection, and these polymorphisms had different effects in various SARS-CoV-2 variants. To confirm these results, however, more research needs to be conducted.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The Pasteur Institute of Iran Ethical Committee, Tehran, Iran, authorized the pilot study and it was carried out in accordance with institutional policies. A written informed consent was obtained from all patients who voluntarily participated in the research. All procedures adhered to the values outlined in the Declaration of Helsinki.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest concerning the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
